articles.title: whois
articles.contents:
Hi. My name is Vincent, AskMeAnything[tm].

Iâ€™m a senior data professional who worked as an engineer, researcher, team lead, and educator in the past. You might know me from tech talks where I attempt to defend common sense over hype in data science.
Iâ€™m especially interested in understanding algorithmic systems so that one may prevent failure. As such, Iâ€™ve had a preference for simpler solutions that scale, as opposed to the latest and greatest from the hype cycle.
In the past Iâ€™ve been:
on the front page of reddit
a digital nomad with an amazing postcard
a preferred Rstudio training partner
co-founder and co-chair of PyData Amsterdam
co-founder of the satRdays Amsterdam conference
a data/open source evangelist with a track record of speaking
co-creator of some open source packages
a youtuber (sortof) for the spacy project
host for the algorithm whiteboard
involved with many data projects
proud creator of calmcode.io
I currently work as a Machine Learning Engineer over at Explosion. Weâ€™re the folks behind tools such as spaCy and prodigy.
Before joining Explosion, I worked as a Research Advocate at Rasa where I collaborated with the research team to explain and understand conversational systems better.
Before that I worked as a consultant at GoDataDriven. I was the first data scientist they hired. Here I helped companies get better at what they do by using data. I had been given a fair amount proper cases with impact for important clients while trying to keep the hype at bay. At some point the hype came from within the company, which was one of the (many) reasons I left.
I believe in open source and donâ€™t mind to evangalise from time to time. I have this blog about slightly less obvious aspects in the world of data science to help people get started as well as to keep a record of things that interest me. Iâ€™m known for speaking at events but also for giving free lectures in data science around Europe.
The future is pretty awesome, all we have to do is build it.
Past Consulting/Training Clients

Old Blog
Iâ€™ve matured my blog in 2018. Some of the old posts can be found here.

articles.title: 404 - not found
articles.contents:
After 5 years I looked at my blog and I noticed I grew up a bit. Many small things that I wrote about simply didnâ€™t stand the test of time anymore. I also wanted to revamp the blog project into something a bit more professional and maintainable for the direction I want to move into professionally the next few years. So the reason that youâ€™re on this page might be because Iâ€™ve switched blogging tool and was forced to move some of the old content.
All the old content should be viewable via an url change.
koaning.io/<oldurl>
becomes
koaning.io/old/<oldurl>
This should give you the original content. If thereâ€™s something really broken: ping me on twitter.

articles.title: Links
articles.contents:
This page contains a bunch of links to pages that Iâ€™ve found useful in the past that I prefer not to forget.
ML/Engineering Resources
pydata many great tech talks
peterbloem has very nice posts on transformers and PCA
evan miller blog series on A/B testing
architecture notes great write-ups and illustrations
Interesting Ideas
tidy data some theory on tidy data
VendorOps tech vs.Â vendor
boring technology good old boring
teach tech together some research on teaching
Great Services
plausible Simple, privacy aware, website analytics.
nounproject Any icons. Amazing.
betteruptime Good uptime service.
Cool Blogs
chip huyen
vicki boykis
jay allamar
stichfix blog
max halford
simon willison
john d cook
peter norvig
lj miranda
bartosz ciechanowski
julia evans
jtash

articles.title: projects
articles.contents:
The projects have piled up over the years, so Iâ€™ve resorted to a tree based view of some of my work. The most up-to-date version of this document can be found on Github.

If you want to create a new blogpost, please run:
distill::create_post("elephants", date_prefix = FALSE)
distill::create_post("cost-of-success", date_prefix = FALSE)
The nice thing about radix is that each document is rather self contained.
If you want to render the entire site locally, please run:
rmarkdown::render_site()
Alternatively you can run this from the terminal;
make build

articles.title: talks
articles.contents:
Iâ€™ve done many talks in the past and Iâ€™ve listed a subset here. Whenever possible Iâ€™ve added links to youtube. If I can make any recommendation, I think these talks are the best recordings of the best talks Iâ€™ve been a part of: link1, link2, link3.
Iâ€™ve also given plenty of internal talks at companies on a wide range of technical topics. These include Zalando, QuantumBlack, ING, bol.com and eBay.
